did.unittitle: George Winfield "Shenandoah Bridge Affair" manuscript narrative 1859-1868
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: George Winfield was a resident of New Market, Virginia. Volume contains a narrative recounting the "Shenandoah Bridge Affair," whose primary Confederate participants were Ashby's cavalry and Chew's battery. According to the biographical sketch in the volume, Winfield was born in 1822.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The George Winfield "Shenandoah Bridge Affair" manuscript narrative was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 1956.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Encoded by Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Elizabeth Shesko, May 2014
Accession(s) described in this finding aid: 56-487
This collection has been given basic processing: materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Volume contains a narrative of the Shenandoah Bridge Affair, which involved as primary Confederate participants Ashby's cavalry and Chew's battery. According to the biographical sketch in the volume, Winfield was born in 1822. It should also be noted that a John Quincy Whitfield was also born in Shenandoah County in 1822, and was Captain of Company B of the 7th regiment, Virginia Cavalry, which was part of Ashby's Cavalry. The author of the volume may be in fact John Q. Whitfield or his relative [online source: A History of Shenandoah County, Virginia, 1989, and Virginia Valley Records: Genealogical and Historical Materials of Rockingham, 2010, both by John Wayland].
